ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

REPORT ON THE SOCIAL SERVICE MASTER PLAN


    1. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Community Development whether his Ministry has accepted the Report on the Social Service Master Plan.

     The Senior Minister of State for Community Development (Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon) (for the Minister for Community Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Report of the Social Service Master Plan is a confidential and internal report submitted by a Work Group comprising representatives from the Ministries of Community

Column: 544

Development, Health, Education and the National Council of Social Service (NCSS). The Work Group was set up by MCD and the NCSS to look at the extent of and possible directions for the delivery of social service in Singapore. The findings and recommendations were strictly meant to serve as internal references for both MCD and NCSS in their planning.

    Nevertheless, as the Member for Hougang has enquired about the report, I will briefly respond to his question.

    One of the recommendations in the Master Plan was the formation of an inter-ministry committee to look into:

    a) compiling data to obtain a comprehensive picture of the various types of social welfare services;

    b) determining their total expenditure, both from the Government and the community; and

    c) the extent of overlaps in welfare effort by the Government and VWOs (voluntary welfare organisations).

    Both MCD and NCSS agreed that a computerisation programme should be put in place in the voluntary sector to obtain the required data. Such a computerisation programme is being implemented and is jointly funded by the Government and the NCSS.

    Other recommendations of the Work Group touch on issues which are already being addressed by both MCD and NCSS. These include:

    a) the setting of standards and the development of resource management for various social service programmes to ensure more efficient and cost-effective service delivery; and

    b) the review of existing services and programmes to ensure their relevance to meet changing needs.

    The Government and NCSS have and will continue to assist VWOs to extend their reach and enhance their service delivery to individuals and families in need. The formation of work groups or

Column: 545

task forces to look at various issues such as the one mentioned by the Member is therefore not uncommon.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, has MCD accepted all the recommendations in the Social Service Master Plan submitted to the Ministry?

     Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon: As I have answered earlier, this is a confidential report and is meant for internal reference. All the recommendations in the Report of the Master Plan are already being implemented. What we are doing first is to implement the recommendation in the Report on the computerisation programme which I have already mentioned just now. The others are already on-going.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: From the Senior Minister of State's answer, can I take it that MCD has accepted all the recommendations in the Social Service Master Plan? Secondly, it was mentioned that it is a confidential report. Why is it confidential in the first place? This is a Social Service Master Plan. It is not something to do with national defence.

     Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon: Sir, it is actually an internal working paper and it is confidential in nature.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Why is it confidential in nature and cannot be released since MCD has accepted the recommendations?

     Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon: It is a matter agreed to between the Government and NCSS.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the Senior Minister of State agree that it would be good for public information to know the future and the Master Plan that we have for Singapore in terms of social service and whether it would be good for Singaporeans to know how the Government would tackle future social service issues in view of the fact that our population is aging? Therefore, I think it is important that the Social Service Master Plan be made known so that we know what are the future plans and what are the commitments of the Government in social service.

Column: 546



     Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon: Sir, I cannot see the usefulness of releasing this working paper to others. It has already been released to the relevant ministries and NCSS for planning and delivery of social service. NCSS also uses it to monitor follow-up action on the recommendations.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, I would like to declare my interest. I am a board member of NCSS. Would the Minister agree that the reason why the paper has remained as a working paper is that there has been some difficulty in obtaining statistics from other ministries and that is the reason why it has not become a full-fledged master plan but has remained as a working paper?

     Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon: Sir, as Dr Soin is a board member of NCSS, I suggest that she bring up this matter and discuss it within NCSS.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I wonder why Dr Soin should bring it up and discuss it within NCSS since the question has been put in Parliament. I would appreciate it if the Senior Minister of State could clarify whether it is true that certain statistics requested by NCSS which are necessary to map out the Master Plan for social service in Singapore could not be obtained from the various Government ministries and I believe part of the data concerns the future Government's commitment in terms of funding social services in Singapore and its development.

     Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon: Sir, the Member wants to know the future commitment of the Government. I can assure him that the Government and NCSS have and will continue to assist all the VWOs to extend their reach and enhance their service delivery to individuals and families in need.

    The Member asked why the report cannot be disclosed. I think there is no need to do so. As I said earlier, the report is confidential and it is an internal document. I do not have my Minister's clearance to release it.

Column: 547

HOUGANG AVENUE 3 IN OLD PUNGGOL ESTATE
(Redevelopment)


    2. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry has plans to redevelop the area at Hougang Avenue 3 in the Old Punggol Estate.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are currently no plans to redevelop the area at Hougang Avenue 3 in the Old Punggol Estate.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is the Minister aware that there is an existing industrial area in the site in question? Is he further aware that in the URA's planning report 1995 for Hougang, the industrial area seems to be rezoned as a residential area?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, the Development Guide Plan designates the land use that we want to earmark for different locations and sites in the medium and long term. So it is a planning intention that the industrial workshops that the Member mentioned will eventually be redeveloped for residential use. But, as I said, right now, we do not have immediate plans to redevelop the area. But if the Member raises it and wants them to be demolished, I am quite prepared to demolish them.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: My query is what is the time-frame, since the Minister says it is a guide plan. But I am sure there is some time-frame as to when it will be developed.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: We have to understand the overall planning process. The URA, as the planning authority, looks at Singapore and tries to fit the various land uses in the various areas. On the Development Guide Plan for this area, for example, looking at the physical attributes of the area, they feel that the land presently occupied by the terrace workshops should be better optimised for residential use. This is the planning intention.

    HDB, as the landlord of the terrace workshops, knows the planning intention. As the landlord, whether it redevelops in

Column: 548

accordance with the planning intention or it continues with its present land use which is also approved by URA, is something for HDB to decide. As he knows, some time last year, I announced that the Government is looking at the overall provision of industrial premises by HDB. We are looking at how some of these industrial premises can be sold to the tenants. At the same time, those industrial premises which are not optimising the land properly would be redeveloped. HDB is still studying the overall redevelopment plans of these industrial premises. Essentially, those which are in high density premises make good use of the land. Industrial shops in multi-storey premises would be retained. As for single-storey terrace workshops, some would be retained because we need terrace workshops to repair cars, etc, and some would be redeveloped. So HDB has not decided whether the particular terrace workshops he is referring to will be redeveloped or not.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister mentioned about the future of terrace workshops. Would he clarify further what would be the guidelines in terms of HDB deciding whether or not a particular terrace workshop would be redeveloped or sold to the sitting tenants?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have explained, the key consideration is optimal use of the land. So industrial premises that are in high density premises, such as multi-storey industrial shops and which are relevant to present day needs in terms of floor loading, car parking requirements, electrical loads, etc., HDB will retain them. Then HDB will decide whether or not it would continue renting them or sell them to sitting tenants along the same line as the sale of shops to sitting tenants. This is the policy which the Government announced last year.

    On the other hand, there are industrial workshops now which are not optimising the use of the land, particularly the single storey terrace workshops. We cannot completely dismantle all of them because some of them do serve an important purpose. For example, they provide car maintenance and servicing and we want

Column: 549

to make sure that these are geographically spread throughout the island to provide the service until alternative premises can be built. So HDB has not decided right now whether or not these particular terrace workshops will be relocated or will continue for some time. But since the Member has raised it, I will ask HDB to take a look. We can always relocate the tenants if they so wish.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister in his answer mentioned about the optimal use of land. I will come back to the site in question. I also note from the same planning report that for the existing area, which is a low-rise commercial and residential area, the plot ratio was increased to 2.8. So I would like to know from the Minister whether there is any plan to redevelop or sell the shophouses to the sitting tenants.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: This is the same approach. The URA, looking at the attributes of the land, feels that in this particular location, the neighbourhood centre ought to be put to better use with a higher plot ratio. As Mr Low Thia Khiang knows, the current neighbourhood centre consists of low-rise shops which are very poor utilisation of the land. So when land is poorly utilised, we are not likely to sell the shops to the shopkeepers because it would perpetuate the poor use of the land. HDB has not decided what to do with the neighbourhood centre. But since Mr Low has raised it, I would ask HDB to take a look. If really there is no real need for a neighbourhood centre, we might as well relocate the shops.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Since the Minister says that they might as well relocate the shops, is he saying that the URA has intention to rezone the area into a completely residential area without shops?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: I am not familiar with the zoning. He is the one who raised the question of zoning. But the DGP for the area is as published by the URA. Whether it is a commercial or residential area with a higher plot ratio, that is left to

Column: 550

URA as professional planners to determine. I am just responding to his point about putting the land to higher intensive use in the DGP. My point is, yes, from the planning point of view, URA wants to put this land to better use, both the terrace workshops as well as the neighbourhood centre. These are in the DGP. It is public information. HDB, as the landlord, has to respond to these planning intentions and they have to determine whether they continue operating as they are or they relocate everybody and make better use of the land. Very frankly, we have not put our minds to it. But since the Member has raised it, I would ask HDB to take a look. If the case warrants, we will relocate the terrace workshops and the shopkeepers in line with the DGP intentions.

Column: 550

WORLD CLASS LAND TRANSPORT SYSTEM
(Motion)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question (18th January, 1996),

    "That this House endorses the Paper Cmd 1 of 1996 on "A World Class Land Transport System" as the basis for developing an outstanding and affordable transport system for Singaporeans.". - [Minister for Communications].

    Question again proposed.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Kampong Glam GRC): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for giving me this opportunity to speak.

    May I, first of all, congratulate the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for coming out with this very comprehensive report in spite of the fact that it has only been set up in September last year, and in three months, it was able to do this wonderful job. I am sure that under the management of LTA we can achieve our objective of having a world class transport system within the next 10-15 years. As my parliamentary colleagues yesterday have already covered a lot of the points, I would like just to cover a few points to complement what has been said yesterday.

    First and foremost on improving the service in MRT stations. Those Members who have travelled in London, Tokyo, and

Column: 551

use the Metro stations and MRT stations, will find it very convenient because at every station there is a time indicating when the next train will be coming. I believe in Singapore this is something that can be introduced to all the MRT stations as a first step for the LTA to improve their services.

    The second point I want to bring up is the use of MRT stations for development purposes. In the Cairnhill Constituency, for example, we have three very good MRT stations at Dhoby Ghaut, Somerset and Orchard Road. Unfortunately, these MRT stations have not been developed. From what I understand, it is because of the stringent conditions laid down by the LTA when it comes to bidding for development purposes. For example, developers may be required to give warranties of up to 30 years that the MRT station will not be damaged. This kind of stringent conditions have discouraged many developers from coming to make their bids and develop these stations. May I suggest that the LTA take up this challenge of being a developer and develop these stations either on their own or in joint venture with one of our developers and set the example and show our developers how such stations can be developed in a manner that can ensure the safety of our trains.

    The next point which I want to bring up is that the LTA in designing new lines, especially the North-East line, should make a proper study of the location of MRT stations. I have also discussed this with my residents in Cairnhill, especially my Residents' Committees at the Tekka Market, and they strongly suggest that the MRT stations should be located somewhere near Tekka Market for the simple reason that every weekend the Tekka Market has a big problem with the foreign workers and one way to solve this problem is to keep these foreign workers, if possible, in the air-conditioned comfort of the MRT station rather than around Tekka Market. I hope the LTA would take these into consideration when they are planning their new MRT stations along the North-East line.

    Another point which I want to bring up is the bus service. At the moment, the bus

Column: 552

commuters wait for long periods of time at certain bus stops. As in Tokyo, when we come out of the Narita Airport to take the airport bus, we always know exactly when the next bus is coming because there is always a clear time indication of the next bus going to which destination and I hope the LTA can use this as an example to have a clear time indicator at all the bus stops, especially the key bus stops along Orchard Road.

    Finally, the LTA, with all its efficiency, could perhaps spend some time immediately to solve some of the transport problems that are causing a lot of concern to our residents, especially along Dorset Road. I have brought this up several times. There is only one bus service No. 131 serving a large area of Farrer Park. Of course, the question of profitability is always there, but I hope the LTA could address this problem and help our residents. Sometimes they have to wait up to an hour for the next bus, and would like to have a better bus service along this route.

     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I commend the LTA for a comprehensive, integrated White Paper on our land transport system. It is an integration of existing stated policies and measures, a reconsideration of some old ideas and suggestions, and further development of new ideas in greater depth, such as the ERP system, the integration of bus interchanges with taxi stands and MRT stations, and the more intensive developments around such MRT stations. The newest proposal which will probably have the greatest impact on all of us is the new financing framework and it is on this section that I will focus the bulk of my attention.

    Firstly, I support the concept of partnership in the financing policy of transport. The White Paper says that the Government provides the transport infrastructure, the commuters pay for the operating cost, while the operators extract efficiency dividends within the service standards and fare structure approved by the PTC. It is not very clear what is included under "transport infrastructure". The obvious items would be roads, MRT

Column: 553

lines, tunnels, bus stops and taxi stands, and so on. In the White Paper on page 43, it is stated that the LTA will provide covered linkways and overhead pedestrian bridges between MRT stations and bus stops to the nearest building. This, I am sure, is good news for the Town Councils in HDB estates as most covered linkways are now built and paid for by Town Councils, or the CCCs with the support of the CIPC. My question is: what about the bus stops in private housing estates? Will linkways be built to connect them to the nearest common area?

    I also agree with the proposed principles of financing. Here again, I have a few clarifications to seek. On page 63, it is stated that the PTC will approve fares based on a few principles, one of which is that the fare revision will be based on what PTC considers to be an acceptable rate of return to the public transport companies. I wonder how the PTC will be able to ascertain what this rate of return should be. Will the PTC make this public? What will they use? Return on assets or return on equity? What will be the rate of return? Is it 10% or 15%? Will these rates of return be different for different transport companies like taxi companies, bus companies or the MRT? Many transport operators, as we know today, are already public-listed and I am sure shareholders would be very interested to know.

    Next, I agree that public transport projects must at least cover operating cost. However, this should be taken at the level of the whole entity, and not route by route, for instance. Without requiring some cross-subsidy between routes, bus companies would abandon loss-making routes to lesser populated outlying areas and private housing estates and compete only along the major corridors. Hence, although I support the policy of minimum cross-subsidy in general, in some instances, economic hurdle rates should not be the only criterion. Other considerations should be taken into account. As far as I can see, and I stand corrected on this, there are few transport policies that have

Column: 554

evolved purely out of economic consideration - many include a wealth tax or wealth redistribution element. For example, in the COE policy, we categorise COEs and we allocate less COEs for the luxury cars so that the lower and middle income will end up paying less for the COEs for small cars. If we were to charge purely for car ownership or road usage, there should be only one type of COE and one price. The same thing for the ARF which is 150%. This is also partly a wealth tax as purchasers of big cars end up paying more taxes even though they use the same road space. The ALS and the ERP will be a pure usage tax, as long as we do not make bigger capacity cars pay more for using the roads. The point I am making here is that since most of our transport policies are not based on pure economics, is there any need to be puritanical in the formulation of other transport polices? Hence, in my view, the decision to build the North-East MRT line should not be based purely on economics.

    Thirdly, I agree with the new sustainable policy on asset replacement, that is, for each generation to pay for the services and assets it consumes. With co-financing from the Government for the purchase of the second set of operating assets, fares can be kept lower for the commuters for a longer period of time. Here, again, this is an indirect decision of the Government to cross-subsidise MRT commuters because the Government revenue is really tax revenue, and the bulk of which, as we know, are paid by people who own cars and seldom use the MRT. Having said that, I am not suggesting that these higher income taxpayers begrudge those who enjoy the subsidy. On the contrary, the challenge for the Government would be to induce such car owners to leave their cars at home, or at/near MRT stations, and take the MRT to the city. The Government should seriously consider building multi-storey car parks at MRT stations, like the Newton Station, Buona Vista or Thomson/Novena stations and other suitable locations, to make it convenient for motorists to do so. For non-motorists living in private housing estates (and there are quite a few, for example, the wives, school-going children and aged parents

Column: 555

who do not have cars), their main problem is how to get to the nearest MRT station or the bus stop without working up too much of a sweat under the heat, or getting drenched from the rain.

    I have no easy immediate solution that is economically viable on its own to offer right now, but I would like to suggest that the LTA study this issue in greater detail. Perhaps, to begin with, the LTA could identify a central bus stop in every private housing estate to develop into a mini-hub and bicycle sheds could be constructed next to this bus stop, together with a taxi stand, to help provide some form of a seamless journey. Amenities like vending machines and public telephones should be installed to make waiting more comfortable. Proper waiting areas for cars could also be added for drivers to pick up their loved ones.

    Finally, before I close, a few words on taxis. Taxis are at the high end of the public transport spectrum, and like private cars, would be the most severely hit by the electronic road pricing system. I am grateful to note that the Government will phase in the ERP charges for taxis gradually over several years. In the White Paper, it is not very clear how this will be done. But in my view, for the system to work well, we have to find a way to have the ERP charges transmitted to the taxi meters straightaway so that taxi commuters can pay for them at the end of their journeys without dispute with the taxi drivers. ERP charges should rightfully be paid by commuters and not by taxi drivers, as for the ALS right now. With ERP, taxis should cruise less and be encouraged to wait at stands. However, to make this more convenient, there should be more taxi stands and the stands should be larger. Today, most taxi stands, as you can see in the city, cannot accommodate more than three taxis. These stands should also be sheltered and covered linkways should be built to connect them to the nearest building. With about 14,000 to 15,000 taxis plying on the roads today, perhaps even bigger waiting areas or holding areas may have to be built in strategic areas of the island if empty cruising becomes too expensive with the ERP.

Column: 556



    I am happy to note LTA's support for differential pricing of taxis to address the problem of supply-demand imbalance during peak hours, and also more flexibility for taxi operators to offer a variety of differentiated services to give commuters more choice according to their needs and pockets. In fact, I had suggested this several times before when I was with NTUC Comfort, but, unfortunately, I could not find support from the PTC then. I am glad the LTA understands the need for this now to meet the different needs of commuters.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the White Paper.

     Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, transportation in urban centres has become a global problem. Hence, much credit must go to the Government, and the Land Transport Authority in particular, for having this strategic mindset to think long term and to think big. Transportation infrastructure very properly belongs in the domain of the public sector, and the entrepreneurial approach adopted by the Government, as demonstrated by this White Paper, is precisely one of those key success factors which has contributed towards Singapore's economic success. Also, knowing the Government, the White Paper is not going to be all words and no action. I am confident that, if approved, this vision will be promptly and efficiently implemented.

    My main comment about the White Paper is regarding financing. In this area, the White Paper leaves a number of questions unanswered. Before I raise these questions, it is useful to summarise four financing principles which have been used in the provision of public services by the Government.

    First, we all know that there is no such thing as a free lunch. A price tag is put on almost everything in Singapore by the Government.

    The second principle is: "you get what you pay for". Take hospitals, for example. If you want the comfort and privacy of an "A" class ward, well, you pay hotel prices.

Column: 557



    The third principle, which applies to the provision of three public goods - health, education and housing - is that of progressive subsidisation. In health, the long-term subsidy targets are: 80% subsidy for "C" class wards; 65% for "B2"; 20% for "B1", and no subsidy for "A" class wards. This is to ensure that even the very low-income can have medical treatment, and that basic health care remains affordable for all. In education, the Government subsidises all development costs of schools and other educational institutions. It also subsidises operating costs to the tune of 98-100% for primary, secondary and junior colleges; 94% for the Institute of Technical Education; 83% for polytechnics; and 75% for universities. I would like to reiterate that this is for operating costs. Similarly for public housing. The Government subsidises about 30% of the total development cost of 3- and 4-room flats, and about 10% for 5-room and Executive flats. This is in order to ensure that HDB flats are affordable to the average income household.
